note.value: The Christian character of the Arabic undertext is proved by the occasional mention of "the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit" (fol. 114r, 117v). The text seems to focus on moral or ascetic issues (e.g., fol. 70r mentions "pure fasting"; fol. 118r mentions "those who consort with males")
Bibliography: J. Monferrer-Sala, "Once Again on the Earliest Christian Arabic Apology: Remarks on a Palaeographic Singularity," Journal of Near Eastern Studies 69.2 (2010): 195-197
